The hall is genrally well maintained but the restrooms Deidre to be kept properly. many of the toilets are stinking without water and cleaning. It seems the management lost control over the staff.

Name: rohitjain296
Title: best place for everything
Review: this is a small but perfect mall containing all types and needs of shop,funcity and theatre in it.its a perfect place for enjoying ur day and shopping..my college is next to it so i use to go when am free

Name: shishirALD77
Title: Average mall
Review: There is nothing very exciting about this mall as the facilities provided are below average and the service as usual is poor. Even the McDonalds in the mall does not have good service as they boast off.

Name: Gnanasingh
Title: PVR Audi 4 Screen Review
Review: PVR Cinemas located in 3rd floor at the end of VR Mall.This review is for AUDI 4 during Avatar English 2D show.Show Time was 10:30AMAdvertisement Till 10:53AM (23 Minutes) Movie Started at 10:54AMAll the audience were extremely irritated on this 23 minutes long advertisements. Seats cushions was comfortable and reclining mechanism was very tight. Floor and Seats was clean and neat. Audio was good. AC could have been better. It wasn't sufficient. Dedicated Counter next to AUDI 9 is available to collect pre-ordered Food and Beverages. Chocolate Donut was good but Cold Coffee was very watery and wasn't good.

Name: Vinoth
Title: Admirable Mall in the city
Review: Hygienic and safe place. Lot of fun and did excellent shopping which covered all branded shops at one place. Most admirable mall in the city with easy accessibility to reach.

Name: Lax
Title: "Unhappy Experience @ VRMall, Chennai"
Review: The design of this mall is very poor in terms of usability. It hauls for long walks with people looking for lifts. One has to walk a minimum distance of 250 mts one way to find the nearest lift or escalator. It's painful when we have to carry the grocery, milk, vegetables with kids, elders, walking for haunting distances to the car park. Just be thoughtful if you are taking kids and elders, for they should be prepared to walk long distances with no support for differently abled ones as well. The support staff inside SPAR were very helpful but the mall services are below average.

Name: Anand
Title: Customers beware of the cleanliness of tables in the food court
Review: The food court looked clean. But I observed the housekeeping staff were mopping the floor and with the same mop they cleaned the table and went to the washbasin and cleaned it with the same mop in full view of the customers. Just wondering about the customers who think the table is clean and putting food stuff over the table and children touching the table !!!Absolutely unacceptable. Will the management take some action over it???

Name: Mano
Title: Thumbs up for VR mall
Review: Compared to other malls in Chennai. the recently built VR mall offers great dine-in, shopping & fun for kids.The best part is the PVR cinemas, which has shining decor with light fixtures. In general, the mall was neat and clean all the time, I have seen the cleaning team is often cleaning the food court. I appreciate their dedication to maintenance. Furthermore, the shopping part was really great, couldn't stop shopping after buying clothes in all branded shops. Tommy Hilfiger & Jack and Jones collection for men was great (didn't visit all shops for men). Ritu Kumar, west side, mango, Vero Moda and lifestyle had a great collection for women. Noticed great watch collections, cosmetic collections as well. Toni & guy offer the best salon & spa service. Basically, you can find everything in one place. The food court looks crowded all the time, especially on weekends. however, the taste of the food from the food court was average. I really recommend the writer's cafe (small dine-in), their pizza was delicious. Karaikudi food tasted good however, the ambience needs to be improved. last but not least, my son really enjoyed the fun city.Overall, it is a great location to spend time together with family, kids & friends

Name: Kumar BK
Title: Surprise for Me
Review: No doubt it‚Äôs one of the very good mall in Chennai but today we have become very surprised when we when we visit we find there is no celebration symbol of our 75 Independent day ,during Christmas when we visit last time we find there is a marvellous decoration arrangement culture program they organise I believe mall management is not not feeling important to celebrate 15th August Independence Day I believe being an Indian we should do at least some  Tirangaa somewhere else in this big mall but it‚Äôs look like a normal day they encourage only Christmas and other regional festival inside the mall only being Indian they must celebrate 15 August another Indian festival being a good brand mall.

The mall is 1. 5 yrs old and almost all the spaces are occupied. The only minus of this mall is the very high car parking charges. Dont take your car if you want to shop and watch a movie. You will be taken for a ride with high car park charges but other than that the mall is a good one.The food choices here is excellent. There is hardly any cuisine which is not served here (one can get all Indian cuisine like Chettinad, Tamil, Kerala, Andhra, Punjabi, North Indian plus international cuisine including American, TexMex, Chinese, Italian, Thai, Lebanese, Turkish, Arab, Japanese and many more fares are served. So many Bakers, Patisserie, Cook specialists, Dessert specialists, coffee lounges Shake specialists, Ice cream vendors from Arun, Hagen Daaz, Movenpick, Ibaco, Cold Stone and many more are present here. The Mall has all retailers from India and International queuing up here. The good thing about the mall is that they have life saving seating arrangements in all levels which is very comforting for old people, parents with babies, Bored husbands etc. The entertainment includes a superb Multiplex, Games for children, Virtual gaming zone. The Mall also has modern office spaces for rentals. In the near future they management plans to open a Pub, Club and a hotel.  Over all it is a one stop shop for a weekend fun.

Name: Anand
Title: Modern mall
Review: The mall is modern, spacious and had many luxury brand outlets.  We mainly visited the mall to get some cute Japanese stationery and traditional dress.Accessing the mall:I think we went to the wrong metro station because none of the auto drivers wanted to take the route to V.R.Mall. They said its a long ride before taking a U-turn, because of the bridge in-between.  Google map showed only half-a-kilometre but there was no road link directly connecting the metro to the mall.Also the drop-off and pick-up zone for auto or taxi is only at the main road, not inside the main gate of the mall.  On a rainy day with water puddles on the street, we were pushed to the edge. The mall real estate owners need to consider easy accessibility for all visitors.

Name: Hari Shankar
Review: VR mall opened its door to Chennai almost a year back and now the place is teeming with people. A few months back there were leeser visitors but there is quantum jump in visitors. The summer and the vacation time could have increased that along with better publicity and management. In terms of choice there is a lot in VR. The best Food joints, Multicuisine restos, International chains, Coffee shops, Creameries, restaurant chains, sweet shops, bakeries etc have set shop here, the best food clothing and leather retailers in India and abroad are present here, the mall has one of the best multiplexes in Chennai and in India itself. The air-conditioning is excellent here.There is loads of parking in the mall. In fact there are there are 3 levels of parking in the basement. Recently the parking was hiked after the multiplex opened but I think after a few complaints they have reduced the parking a little bit which is good. If the security staffs dont speak Tamil nor English. It is a must for them to speak the local language. Nearly 30 - 40 shops are still not open which is not good. A few things are missing here. A decent pub and a club would be great, a few shops selling exquisite Indian handicrafts, Sculptures, Indian carvings and memorabilia   would be a great addition. A decent sized hotel would have been great here. I hope VR Chennai is hearing this. If not for all this I would have given VR mall a perfect 5 star.

Title: Up coming mall
Review: Went to VR Chennai mall last week especially to purchase from Spar super/hyper market. The facade of the mall sports a multi-coloured design based on the traditional gopuram. The mall is relatively big one with different outlets in four floors. The prices of many house hold, grocery, dress and etc, etc items were really low in Spar. Went for lunch at the food court located in the fourth floor. All veg and non-veg outlets selling items at much higher price. While entering the mall at the parking lot was informed about the parking charges priorly that for first hour it is Rs.40 and for every additional hour extra Rs.30 will be added.  I have just crossed one hour and paid Rs.70. In that GST was Rs.10. Too high parking fee. From Koyambedu bus-stand it is about 1 km.

Name: Team VR
Review: Went twice during the month of December 2018. The mall was crowded due to Christmas vacation. Tried for movie on the first visit and couldn‚Äôt get the tickets had to roam around the mall and booked the movie tickets and went for second time. Ample car parking available. The food court though it is small area has different combinations South Indian Veg only, pizzas, North Indian mix with Non-Veg, ice cream parlours, Madras coffee shop etc, some of restaurants are under construction. Some shops accept food zone special card whereas Dominos pizza doesn‚Äôt accept them . Why this two different policy needs to clarified. The VR zone was totally a waste of time. The shops are not so big branded ones, but then the taste differs as to what you plan to purchase.The movie theatre in which we saw Spiderman must be around 200 -250 capacity but the interesting part was long queues for popcorns and Nachos. Many of the sales counters was not fully operational and it seems like the mall was more interested in selling extra large sized popcorns rather than promoting the movies. Some chilling art work on the lower floors needs to be really appreciated. The writings on walls depicting old songs praising Lord Krishna is really wonderful ‚ÄúMaadu Meikum Kanne Nee Poga ‚ÄúSome light music band live was entertaining. This too be promoted to encourage music lovers Overall the food cost, car parking cost to be reduced so that more people enjoy. The entrance and exit chaos leading to busy stretch needs to be taken care. Do visit once yo have a feel of it

Name: Hooray H
Title: Must see!
Review: A little piece of England here since 1680!Remarkable. Layers of history before your eyes.Well maintained. Peaceful.There is a cafe in the square behind the fort that does excellent Madras coffee.Unfortunately, w missed the Rafael Painting.Have to visit again.

Name: SingaporeGirl
Title: Like a good book, ignore the cover and look inside
Review: You will want to walk slowly throughout this church and read the eulogies and memorial plaques to understand why you should not miss visiting this historic colonial church in Chennai. Regardless of your background or faith, you can not help but be touched by the fickleness of history in who survived and thrived and those who died, whether in battle or of disease, whether in their 20s or 60s. It is an extremely moving experience that anyone who is interested in the colonial history of India and for that manner, all of Southeast Asia for many fell in service in Burma, Malaysia and other lands, should not miss.

Name: Dwightcr
Title: Church from the 1600's
Review: St. Mary's Church is  located within the grounds of Fort St George.  The church is the oldest the oldest British building in India.  It's plain inside but ozzes history.

Name: AURELIO L
Title: nice church
Review: i think that the colonian churches are very interesting and can teach so much to us,st mary cathedral is nice but not so so important go if you have time

Name: Praveenop
Title: The oldest Anglican Church in Asia
Review: The St. Mary's church is one of the oldest church in India and Asia. Mr. Elihu Yale ( who started the Yale University in US) was married here when he lived in Chennai. Also this place has a masterpiece Raphael in its hall. Yes !!! an original Raphael masterpiece . I did not believe it until I saw it .

Name: Valavanur Natar... K
Title: A DETAILED WRITE UP ON ST MARY'S CHURCH IN FORT ST GEORGE CHENNAI
Review: St Mary's in Fort St George, Madras - An  Oldest Anglican Church If one is a visitor to Chennai from any part of the world or India,  it surely will be worth their while to visit this historical Anglican Church built inside fort St George,  the Seat of Power fir  the Government of Tamil Nad,  even today.St Mary's in Fort St George, Madras was consecrated in the year 1680 which makes it one of  the oldest Anglican church in Asia ,with very important historic significance in the evolution of Chennai or Madras .Sadly history tells us that  during the 3-year occupation of Fort St George by the French 1746 - 1749 , it was put to use as a water storage .The church is within Fort St George , a fort built by the British  as a  secure trading post and  completed in  1653 and then gradually kept expanding  to its present size and then went  on to become and remain the seat of the state government even today .. The church was built with private contributions, with  East India Company,  who developed the  fort , and on its own had no part in its Construction actually.  Streynsham Master 1640 - 1724,  was appointed governor  in 1678 after spending number of years with the Company based in Surat on the west coast of India .Soon after taking up the appointment in January 1678 he determined, entirely on his own initiative and without reference to London Office ,  that the settlement needed a proper church. Until then divine services had been held in the largest room in the fort, the  common room, which served as a chapel besides being put to other uses. Master and his colleagues in council contributed about half of the 800 odd Pagodas raised that is  about 400 sterling pounds in those  days and  Elihu Yale, a Merchant on the Company's rolls contributing  15 Pagodas. Rest came mostly from other Merchants in the Company's service. William Dixon was the  Chief Gunner of the East India Company's Madras Establishment and also an  Engineer  to the Army .The Governor instructed him to build the church. East India Compaany later did contribute to its  construction .The church was 80 feet by 56 feet when  originally built with  the separate tower added  sometime later and conjoined to the old church built by Dixon .¬†The church resembles a  fortified structure to meet the security needs of those days and  St Mary's church almost finished as a bomb proof structure with over 5 ft thick walls having a  vaulted roof of 4 ft thick maximum and 2 ft minimum.Its  window shutters are about two foot wide ang more than 6 ft height .When the French bombarded   Madras in 1746, the church was  one building in the fort,  to come through unscathed. The French did manage to damage the steeple though , when they attacked again in 1758 but that was not built by Dixon, since the tower was added only around  1701 and a spire in 1710.Dixon, first  castellated the parapet and  never  used wood in the structure  to render it fire proof in the event of bombing.The interior looks beautiful although the exterior is  squat looking as a fortress should ..It has a nave with two aisles and a gallery at the far end from the altar. The roof  is vaulted with rose ornaments in relief on the curved ceiling with classical touches .The church itself derived its name Since construction commenced on 25th March 1678, My Lady Day, so it came to be christened as  the church of St Marys and consecrated on its completion on  Thursday, the 28th of October 1680. The Fort had had a Chaplain on its establishment since 1676 and the incumbent in 1680 was Richard Portman. He obtained  a special licence from the Bishop of London to consecrate the church with Streynsham Master assusting him .Being the oldest Anglican place of worship in whole of  Asia and it is  therefore associated with a number of events  in British Indian history .This  is what makes this church so special, in addition to its construction and its charming interior.The church now maintained by ASI of India still maintains a register, which is continuous since its 1680 inception, well  preserved and the volumes from 1680 to 1819 are loaned to the Fort St George Museum, a stone's throw away from the church and certainly worth a visit. A copy in thick vellum of the original register, copied in the 18th century, is on display inside the church and all original records from 1819 onwards are also available in the church for inspection, .which I did nor personally see.The credit of first entry goes to the marriage of Elihu Yale to Catherine Hynmers, on 4th November 1680,  and within a week of the original consecration with the Governor, Streynsham Master, giving away the bride. The lady was the widow of Joseph Hynmers, a Member in Council and friend of Yale, who had died in April of that year and David Yale, the son of Eli and Catherine Yale, is buried in the original churchyard, having died in 1688. Yale went on to become Governor of Madras between 1687 - 92   later endowed a building after his name in the college which later came to be called Yale University,  from his personal earning as a trader.The most famous marriage recorded in the church register is, of course ,that of Robert Clive to Margaret Maskelyne, 18t February 1753. The painting in the  alter is  by George Willison 1741 - 97 , a Scottish artist, who came out to Madras in 1774  with  the patronage of Muhammad Ali, Nawab of the Carnatic, who  himself  ane to be based in Madras by this time. St Mary's church in thii  Fort  deseves to be presented to the world for its rich heritage and history of British in India .Its heattening to lnow  it is under the very good care of the Church of South India and the maintenance is being taken care of by ASI ,India This church in my view takes its place of  pride in the historu  of Chennai.

Name: JulietheCruiseDir
Title: Lovely church with some misspelled English in stained glass windos
Review: Lovely cathedral in white, and reportedly one of the oldest Catholic Churches in Tamil Nadu.  Older Mary statue carved in wood.  Several of the wooden idols and stained glass had English writing including one that said ‚Äúsee my heart an mercy to you all‚Äù. Second or third language even for the craft people who made.

Name: Karpagavalli
Title: inside the fort
Review: This church is inside the fort and the building itself speaks of its British age ,hope this is one the early churches built by them in India, still can be better maintained as it houses lots of history of the city and it's people.

Name: SteveS1970
Title: Lovely church
Review: A lovely old church within Fort St. Goerge.very historical with a lot of memorials to British Regiments who fell in the wars on the walls. A very old wordly church that is worth a visit if you are passing.

Name: Ukienomad
Title: Don‚Äôt go out of your way
Review: A lovely church near Fort George that is beautiful on the inside and outside. It has beautiful stained glass windows. We were able to view two weddings while we were there with women coming in with their colorful saris. It made it worth while to stop into this church. And in the back Of the church don‚Äôt miss St Thomas tomb, one of the original 12 apostles.

Name: Timothy L
Title: Historical Church
Review: Very old church with history of Portuguese and British influences over the centuries. Quiet and reflective escape from the noises of Chennai

Name: Peter B
Title: Must see if westerner visiting Chennai
Review: Interesting and historical church within the grounds of Fort St George. Apparently the oldest Anglican Church East of Suez.  Lovely quiet gardens around the church as well as interesting historical artefacts and monuments inside.

Name: Charles_and_Susan
Title: OK but closed
Review: We visited here as part of our tour of the Fort St George. It looks good from the outside but unfortunately it was closed when we went, Sunday afternoon. We're told it's the oldest Christian Church in India.

Name: Komator
Title: Average church
Review: St Mary's church is inside Fort St George. The church is nice, but nothing exceptional. If you're in the area and you visit Fort St George, it's worth the visit, but that's it.

Name: Paul Henry
Title: A historical delight
Review: This is a rare experience. The premises are very well maintained. The atmosphere there literally transports you back 200 years and over.

Name: Jeannie2207
Title: A pretty church with a lot of history.
Review: Now completely surrounded by hustle and bustle of a busy city, this once delightful church has sadly become a shadow of its former self, but it‚Äôs still interesting to visit and get an idea of how the city and community was in the 19th century

Name: scud56
Title: Historic old church with a really nice ambiance
Review: To find St Mary's church (and the Fort George museum) you now need to get through the significant security around the Chennai administration complex that has taken over this whole area of the old fort. Hence, there may be a large queue to navigate - the police may help you queue jump if its obvious that you are a tourist rather than someone seeking to go into the administrative buildings.Once at the church the shift in ambiance is palpable and its worth spending some quiet reflective time just wandering around and taking in the history of the place and the many lives are referenced there in the plaques and gravestones.

Name: Issac0616
Title: Oldest pipe organ in Chennai
Review: Don't miss to visit this church located inside St.George Fort. Plan for a day when there is no TN assembly proceedings to avoid the crowd and minimal security checks. Must visit in Chennai. One of the oldest church built bY British people. Don't miss to see the Oldest pipe organ in Chennai. Old cemetery of Bristish era can be found nearby. Antique look and building atmosphere takes you to the Bristish time when you read the epitaph of many officers buried here.

Name: ARedRose
Title: Beautiful Old Church
Review: I enjoyed the peace and quiet of this little church that seemed somewhat neglected.  Apparently Clive of India is buried here, but I could not find his grave or any reference to him in the church.  Probably the best part of the Fort but you can walk around and see older parts, very run down with lots of rubbish about

Name: David H
Title: Beautiful interior
Review: You can include a visit to St Mary‚Äôs with a visit to the St George Fort Museum.They do not seem to encourage visitors on Sundays.Entrance is free.

Name: Lovetotraveldubai
Title: Waste of time
Review: Only interesting because it‚Äôs reference to British officers and governors in whose honour there are few plaques and reliefs. Church is dingy and unloved.

Name: Somil A
Title: Church only for CATHOLIC community
Review: i visited this church on 25/12/17 with my wife. It was nicely decorated with LED's, flower and toys. Very neat and clean church. it was around 8 PM  father started evening prayer and after finishing prayer he came down and start giving 'PRASADAM' to people . All who so ever present in church stood up in a single line and wait for his turn.to my surprise father is not giving prasadam to everybody. i noticed the same from long distance however don't know what is happening exactly. when me and wife reached to father he asked prasadam (sweet, holy water or whatever) is only for catholic so he cant give to us. this happened with many people there and everybody was shocked how come a priest can do this kind of behavior with the children.otherwise good place for prayer.

Name: Peter S
Title: Wonderful relic - worth visiting
Review: St Mary's church's origins date back to the very beginnings of English rule in Madras - the gravestones that cover the ground inside its gates testify to that. The fabric of the church's interior is later, but is still evocative of the British period, not least in the many memorials on the walls.But the most impressive thing about the church is that it is not just an historical monument - I was there on a Wednesday lunchtime, and there were easily a dozen people using it, for prayer, Bible-reading or (possibly) having a quiet snooze. Most were members of various Indian uniformed services or government servants employed nearby in the huge and busy fort.There was an interesting-looking booklet on sale 'A Walk around St Mary's' which I would have bought but there was no one around to take my money. Still, it was a most enjoyable and interesting visit: highly recommended.

Name: Lilian J
Title: Historical church
Review: History lessons can be learnt at this old but well maintained church which has had a number of illustrious visitors too.

Name: worldwomantourist
Title: Very old & Beautiful Church
Review: St Mary's Church is located in Fort St.George. it is also known as "the westminster Abbey of the East. This church was constructed in 1678 AD by the British. The pillars are carved from Burma teak adds beauty and strength to the building.

Name: Zinzan6
Title: An Outstanding Church
Review: This is one of my favorite churches across the world. It‚Äôs a real find and you should insist on a visit if you have a few hours in Chennai. Would recommend using a guide but it‚Äôs not necessary for you to really enjoy. After traveling through the city it‚Äôs great to find an oasis of calm and contemplation in the city. The historical references through memorials in the church offer considerable insight into the early period of British engagement in India. It‚Äôs a great location to relax, soak in some history and respect for religious locations. Absolutely add to your Chennai agenda.

Name: Joji J
Title: "the oldest British building India and oldest Anglican church"
Review: Also know as "the westminster Abbey of the East" this oldest British building in India this church was constructed in 1678 AD. The church is in Fort St.George and the church building has two aisles and a nave and west end of the nave has a spacious gallery resting on carved Burma teak pillars and a tower to the west of the nave. We can find several tomb stones inscribed in Latin and Portuguese and the list of notable persons buried can also be found in the church. The church is keeping records of Marriages and baptisms too and regular services are conducted here. We will wonder how the church existed for almost four centuries when we visit this church and while visiting Chennai, St. Mary's church is a must see place.

Name: Partha C
Title: Old British Church
Review: Built in 1680, and within Fort St George. Nice place. It is a must see place. Old records are preserved here.

Name: BrunoMascarenhas
Title: This is the Old Church East of Suez and is within Fort St.George
Review: This church still has regular ServicesThis is a Old Church East of SuezThe Old Baptism and Marriage Records are preservedThe Staff are Friendly and eager to help

Name: teebee68
Title: a quiet church
Review: if you are visiting chennai , please do go to this church. tucked away behind the seat of the govt of tamil nadu this church is beautiful. a must visit.

Name: Biddy50
Title: India's oldest surviving British church
Review: Consecrated in 1680 & situated within Fort St George. This is a small but calm church within a very busy area. There is quite tight security around the site, as there are many Legislative buildings, but worth a wonder round.

Name: NeilandBarbara
Title: Well worth a visit
Review: It's a must visit site if you are in Chennai's fort St George area. More of a cathedral than a church. Very peacefull and well worth a visit. There was a service on then we visited and it was packed. We would have liked to have spent more time looking around, but it felt intrusive to linger too long.

Name: Hilarian_Felix
Title: An Ancient Co-Cathedral
Review: This is one of the ancient church's and has the status of Co-Cathedral and is there in existence approximately for more than 100 years. This is one of the popular place of worship for we Roman Catholics. St.Mary's Church is also popularly known as St.Anthony's Church by people because of the miracles where veneration is down to Saint Anthony and is believed strongly that when they come here and pay their devotion to St.Anthony their problems regarding their health gets cured, not only this people also believe that evil spirits which are cast upon people also get cured. Every Tuesday of the week is considered to be a special day to visit this church and every first Tuesday of the month is considered to be very special and lots of people come in to worship to St.Anthony. The faith on this church has no religious difference, not only Christians also Hindus, Muslims and people from other religion come here. People from different parts of the Chennai city as well as people from other parts of the country and even foreigners come here to worship. Adjacent to it is St.Mary's Higher Secondary School where I did my schooling, so I was lucky enought to do my prayers daily till I was studying in that school. Now I go and worship every Tuesday on my way home and pay my devotion to Mother Mary and St.Anthony. If you are deeply in trouble of your sorrows, sins and problems in your life leave everything behind and come with faith and your problems will be solved.

Name: Anjal s
Title: Excellent ambience
Review: Nice place to visit if you are on a pilgrimage.u can spent some time here if you are in some real stress or tension

Name: Krish M
Title: Pious place
Review: Nice attraction and a beautiful church to visit. Placed at a wonderful location and at the heart of the city, quite spiritual.

Name: eskaykannan
Title: Good calm place
Review: Been there quite a few times... Quiet place if you are seeking calm time... Since this is inside the Secretariat of Tamil Nadu, nowadays may have trouble getting in due to security..

Name: Akash K
Title: ancient church
Review: This church is located behind secretariat Building.Close walk from Fort Museum.this is the first anglican church in asia.

Name: Northeagle66
Title: Nice little old church.
Review: This Church has a lot of history and is within the perimeter of Fort St George.  We have been told the roof can support bombardment,  Graves on the floor at the exterior of the Church are very interesting.  Nice short visit.  I brought back a small and interesting brochure sold in the Church: "A walk round St Mary's"

Name: maryinchina
Title: Historic place in the middle of a busy area
Review: I went to this church because the neighbouring Fort museum was closed (holiday) and had little else to do. It was cool to see the very old tomb markers some from the 17th c.

Name: vasan224
Title: another spiritual place in chennai
Review: St Mary's church is one of the peaceful place to pray. a good place to visit. one of the oldest chruch in chennai.

Name: Gregory D
Title: Oldest church in India
Review: A little hard to find as it is behind the huge Secretariat building, but well worth it if you are interested in history. Built in 1680, it is the oldest remaining church in India. Although needing some repair and restoration, the building is solid and very impressive. Take the time to read some of the commemorative plaques to British officers, administrators, missionaries and their wives and families to get some idea of the hazards of colonial service. Certainly we got a lot out of our visit.

Name: ChrisJS51
Title: Attractive Anglican church near the coast in Chennai
Review: Attractive, peaceful Anglican church. Needs a bit of work doing to it, but no doubt this is because of a lack of funding. Good history and worth a visit, though access is tricky as it is within the Fort St George base.

Name: Joanne
Title: unimpressive
Review: Very small - you could visit it in 5 minutes and not much to look at. Close walk from Fort Museum. Only thing interesting in walking area was an e-toilet (I had never seen one before).

Name: raja p
Title: Westminster Abbey of the East
Review: this is the first anglican church in asia.good strong structure.this is a boob proofed church built in 300 yrs ago.this is closed on sunday for visitors.

Name: balakec
Title: Oldest church with loads of history
Review: This church was designed by military engineer which is evident from the walls whose layers are resistant to enemy artillery. This church is where greats like Elihu Yale, Robert Clive and  other personalities got married. This one can be visited while exploring the Fort and Clive house. It is situated parallel to the Clive's House.

Name: JumboMumbai
Title: Oldest English church
Review: That is what St Mary's church is the oldest in the country.  So also the graves in the tombs that are 300 years old.  It also hosues a prayer house within the church where some important mariages took place.

Name: LuizDutraNeto
Title: Visiting the oldest Anglican Church in the whole Asia!
Review: While strolling along Chennai's beautiful "Fort St. George", you will certainly have your attention caught by the small and mystic "St. Mary's Church". Its construction started exactly on March 25, 1678 (the "Our Lady's Day",  when Christians celebrate the day of the Annunciation of Virgin Mary) and was therefore devoted to St. Mary. It is considered the oldest Anglican Church in Asia, as well as the oldest British building in India. Stop in for ten minutes, enjoy its simplicity, its peace and say a prayer. Beautiful wooden and glass furnishings and a fantastic painting above the main altar, picturing the "Last Supper", with caractheristics of the Raphaelite school, complete the scene Enjoy!

Name: sunil k
Title: OLD CHURCH
Review: Its Ancient Church. when the Eastern indian Company  first Church almost 16th to 17th Century , most of arts made in white stone ....

Name: Mani K
Title: Oldest Architect of the British
Review: St Mary's Church is one of the oldest church of the British Time . It stands healthy even after decades together . The beauty of the church lies in the silence maintained during the prayer

Name: Madhanmohan C
Title: Nice place
Review: Nice place for praying god in chennai. Well maintained church which has his unique qualities for attracting all outstation devotee for prayer on sunday.

Name: kowie55
Title: Priceless heritage building
Review: This is the place where General Robert Clive married Margaret Maskelyne. Governor Yale (after whom Yale University is named) got married here too. The three daughters of Job Charnock (founder of modern Calcutta) got baptised here. Governor General Warren Hastings romanced his future wife in the street nearby. And there is a lovely photograph of Madras 150 years ago. At the altar there is a nice painting of the Last Supper.  And there are number of memorials for the VIPs of the Raj,  whom we studied about in school!. Tourists are not welcome on Sundays, because that is the day of religious services. It is worth visiting on any other day.

Name: Davindia167
Title: St. Mary's Church
Review: It is a nice monument of the British regime, located within the Fort! Serene atmosphere within and well preserved!

Name: infoexpertx
Title: Nice
Review: Pretty small church designed to be bomb proof.  Some beautiful memorials great if you are an an aficionado of church architecture or colonial history.

Name: velayudhan
Title: Oldest Architect of the British
Review: St Mary's Church is one of the oldest church of the British Time . It stands healthy even after decades together . The beauty of the church lies in the silence maintained during the prayer .

Name: girieshm24
Title: oldest chruch
Review: located inside st george fort and its really a very old chruch with marble statues ,this place have particular timing for visitors and for doing mass

Name: Bharatbackpacker
Title: Peaceful Church
Review: St. Mary church is a 300 year old church inside Fort St. George. The architecture is lovely and visitors should not forget to look at painting of the last supper over the altar. the painting is painted by unknown artist, but, is similar to that one painted by Raphael's one in Vatican. Photographers may find it a challenge to snap the church from outside without a wide angle lens.

Name: Arrul
Title: Oldest Anglican church!!!
Review: This one is so special coz its inside the Tamil Nadu state Secretariat and its functioning ,Oldest Anglican church and be there to experience the colonial period of India.lovely church and much of its old world charm has been preserved.very peaceful place .

Name: shymathans
Title: St Mary Church
Review: Enjoyed the time that spent in this church...peaceful area. the architecture is too good, wonderful designs

Name: huntersbro
Title: Lovely old English church
Review: St Mary's, built 1680, is the oldest Anglican church east of the Suez, and much of its old world charm has been preserved.

Name: harish k
Title: Not like before
Review: Standard definitely reduced. May be bit carried away with their tag. Very pricey with minimal quantity. Not a pleasant experience

Name: KeralaLily
Title: a peaceful beautiful place
Review: tucked away and often overlooked, St Mary's is a lovely church, well worth the visit. The information about the site is put up on large slabs, so no need to take a guide along with you - just wander in sit down and soak it in.

Name: ajusoni
Title: Peaceful Place
Review: St Mary Church has fabulous history and Loved the peace and quiet here,. Well worth to wander around.

Name: boy816
Title: Happy tour
Review: While travelling all the way to chennai  and seeing such a lovable churh once in a time is very exciting.

Name: ananth337
Title: Historical Anglican Church of Chennai
Review: If you are visiting Chennai,it is a must see,especially if you are a student of Indian History.It is the oldest Anglican Church of the East,where Robert Clive of the East India Company,who helped establish British rule in India, got married in this Church.It is well maintained in the pristine surroundings of Fort St.George,and quiet,inspite of the Fort being the seat of the Tamil Nadu Legislative Assembly and office of The Chief Minister.

Name: lakshmanan s
Title: Very historical
Review: if you go there week ends you can spend lots of time reading the English tomb stones inside and out side the church especially the one of Elizabeth baker the oldest tomb stone in India.Very quiet place

Name: yesuthasen
Title: an oasis of calm in a busy city
Review: The oldest Anglican church east of Suez is located inside Fort St George. Its is not just a monument but a living church where services are conducted regularly. It is a very charming building steeped in history and reminiscent of old churches in England.with marble statues and plaques that record early British times. The church also has  a magnificent pipe organ.The garden behind the church is a place one can sit and feel the peace

Name: clementwill
Title: A beautiful church that merits a visit
Review: The oldest Anglican church in the country. This is a must visit, located inside the Fort St George grounds, regular services are conducted every Sunday. The interiors takes one back to the British times and the acoustics of the church along with the pipe organ which is one of the few surviving ones in the city make the experience unique.

Name: FRANCIS R
Title: Historical & valuable.
Review: This church is part of the British History in India.The church building , the architecture , the displays and the documents are valuable .This church should be preserved for posterity & as an insight into Christian religion in British India.

Name: Hells72
Title: Great piece of history
Review: Loved the peace and quiet here, fabulous history. Well worth a wander around. You need to go i to,the fort and be security checked... And sign in. don't let that put you off.

Name: CyrilGubbi
Title: Ols charm
Review: This is an Old but Nice church. But now it is a busy Government office area. Can visit for its old charm and structure.

Name: nishkalav
Title: Must visit
Review: It's divine.. am not a christian but would encourage every one to visit this place. It's very old church with a beautiful organ that is in working condition.  There are about 18 organs in chennai and only few of them work. This church is the only Anglican Chris outside Europe.  Building will look old and majestic.

Name: Kadirvelan S
Title: Historical Church!
Review: It is situated inside the Fort premises which also houses the State Assembly and secretariats. A bit uncomfortable for tourists?

Name: Sockalingam
Title: Historic Chruch
Review: A historic Church with beautiful architecture blended with the history of chennai . A must go for everyone

Name: Vijay_Christy
Title: Historical Church
Review: Had been here with my college group back in 2007 and recently went here last year along with my life...My wife sings in a group and her group was invited here and i enjoyed going there

Name: Suneel1025
Title: City best church
Review: St Mary's Church is great and old historical Church.  Peaceful and silent and divine area.  for pay best church

Name: SoulSearcher91
Title: Blessings in Abundance
Review: This is one church that has personally given me several miracles and I have led so many of my friends and family here. I would urge you to do the same.

Name: Sathiyan621
Title: St.Antony Church
Review: one of the old church. Never forgettable memories.   Saint. Antony status is very famous in this church.

Name: 827ram
Title: Calmness
Review: nice place, calm, can learn a lot, chennai is full of hidden history and mistry......ned to go around to fine many like this....

Name: MYSTICALFORT
Title: Blissful Church
Review: Visited the place along with my sweetheart. Both of us liked the place very much and enjoyed spending some time praying to have a peaceful life.

Name: chellamonk
Title: Mary's church
Review: Very old church still being maintained nicely by our government. One of the important places in chennai. Worth visiting?

Name: neethuvarkey24
Title: Awsome!!
Review: i had great time. i spend around 2 hrs.. did meditation. felt very relaxed.awsome place to spend time with family and children

Name: greg j
Title: A beautiful and historic space
Review: St Marys in a beautiful building with a feeling of great history. As with many old churches one can feel the past that seeps out of the stones and the silence that hangs in the air. If you are into old churches it is well worth a visit

Name: CyrilGubbi
Title: Old but very good
Review: This is a lovely church near fort. This was built by the British but very well maintained. Must be more than 100 years old.

Name: Bill H
Title: St Mary's in the fort
Review: This little gem appears to be missed by most visitors to Chennai. If you're visiting the fort and/or the museum then search it out. It's walls are filled with history from the centuries of the British Raj. It's also a quiet corner of the administrative centre of Chennai - a reason why you'll be stopped from taking cameras in to the fort area.

Name: ASocial N
Title: Beautiful, peaceful oasis
Review: If you've come to the Fort for the museum,then you should most definitely head on over to the church.  You'll need to walk towards the back of the museum, past the Army Parade ground and then reverse your steps to exit the location.The oldest Anglican church in India is reasonably well maintained and a delight to visit.  (there is no visiting on Sundays) It's open to visitors from 9-5pm, there is a service at 0915.  Here you'll find the register of marriages referencing the founder of Yale in the USA, you'll find memorial plaques to individuals of years gone by and a peaceful oasis.  The small garden is quite lovely and well worth a short wander.

Name: James G
Title: Worth a visit
Review: Certainly worth it if you have time it is full of history. The place is cool and quite in the hustle and bustle of a working location.

Name: janardhanan n
Title: First Anglican Church East of Suez
Review: St.Mary's church is inside the Fort st. george compound in chennai. This was the first anglican Church to be built east of Suez!! The Fort St. george is being used as the Government secretariate and hence all the security checks to get into the compound to visit the church. Once you enter there you see a beautiful old church with a lot of memorials for all those British soldiers and traders who died in India building the empire. It is very nicely maintained. Old artefacts are carefully preserved includind the old stone baptism tray.

Name: Zinzan6
Title: Tranquil in the end
Review: I visited with my 3 children.  The fort itself is very busy and it took us a while to locate the church. Once there we spent about an hour exploring. Outside we checked out the headstones with the 'pirate' headstone getting the most attention. Inside we explored the various memorials and spent some time sitting inside.  It was coming up for sunset and that added to the atmosphere. Would recommend braving the crowd for some special tranquility.

Name: Attig45
Title: Wonderful old Anglican church, the first in India
Review: In the grounds of Fort St George, Chennai, this little church is a wonder, with a beautiful nave, memorials, bibles, stained glass and paintings. It was built in 1678 and is still a working church.

Name: warmemorialjunkie
Title: A journey into the past
Review: Ancient little church ..walls covered with plaques from the 1700's, in memory of British Military officers, doctors and their wives and children, who've died everywhere from Rangoon to the Cape of good hope,Penang,Sumatra...drowned in the Godavari..killed by tigers..died in war...died during seiges..died at sea ..                                  An unexpectedly emotional glimpse into the tragic lives of people from another era...take the time to walk around and read all the memorials on the walls and the floor of the church.

Name: gupreen
Title: Raja Ravi Varma and many originals
Review: For the art lovers, this place is a must go! There are several wonderful paintings, all original pieces! You can keep admiring at your peaceful length of time! Unfortunately the sculpted masterpieces are totally out of bounds for public. You have to admire them from the gallery above. But the paintings make up for this. The original British era paintings, modern art and above all - the original Raja Ravi Varma paintings!BTW, the entrance itself is passed by a structure so lovely and majestic with a beautiful door! Although, it is only the side building where the beautiful art pieces are located. There is a small collectibles shop. Also worth a visit if you are looking out for some steals. Overpriced though :)

Name: AURELIO L
Title: it s a must
Review: i have no idea about how much rooms of this museum you will be able to see,the main problem is that so much rooms are closed and it s not possible to see them ,but this is an interesting museum where you will be able to see indian art

Name: MarkfromtheIsland
Title: Review of the bronze gallery - main museum is closed
Review: So the main museum here is closed because nobody noticed the roof was leaking till all the art was damaged.  That pretty much sets the stage for why I rated this poorly.The bronze gallery has some beautiful work in it but it's marred by a total lack of care.The ground are all dug up for some renovation work.  That's understandable.  But dumping loads of gravel across the walking paths isn't.  Having a gallery with the air conditioning out and not expected to be working for 60 days isn't.  Allowing a large group of elementary school children to roar around screaming while other visitors are trying to see the sights isn't.  The display and display cabinets being full of dust both inside and outside isn'tGet it together here.  These are historical artifacts, not the contents of your aunt Karen't garage.

Name: Karpagavalli
Title: Has to improve the maintenance
Review: The building was built by the British during their period here but now is a museum. The place is so vast with 6or7 building s each exhibits the old era products and sculptures and all.

Name: KANewYork
Title: Local art
Review: Entry tickets can be bought adjacent to the main gate from where you enter. Different rates for Indians and foreigners. If you want to take pictures you can pay extra. The complex contains many buildings. Many were closed or in the process of renovation. The anthropology section was open partially.. just a couple of rooms on the ground floor displaying weapons. The highlight was clearly the Bronze gallery with some pieces dating back to the 9th century AD. Most are forms of gods and goddesses. The large nataraja or dancing shiva statue from Tanjore is the the one whose copies are sold everywhere in India from small trinket sized to large show pieces. No photography was allowed in here.The complex has lots of shade from a large number of trees, so it‚Äôs relatively pleasant walking in here as compared to the city streets.

Name: Nigel G
Title: Nice Selection of Art
Review: The National Art Gallery is within the National Museum compound. I was thoroughly confused here when I arrived regarding the ticketing and by the advice given by my driver. You buy your ticket at the ticket office. There is NO ticket for the National Art Gallery - it is only a National Museum ticket which covers all six houses of the complex. That's the first mystery solved. Second - why do I need to go to Gallery 1 - Mogul Architecture if I want to see the art - that's because you need to activate your ticket there and if you want to buy a camera pass that's where you get it from for R250. Now you are free to go anywhere and in any order. Did unit 1 as I was there then moved the the Art Museum in building 6. It's very messy as there is much renovation going on. You are told to disregard the no photography signs if you have purchased the camera pass.Arrived at building 6 and the lower floor was all about handicraft and models etc. True art on the two upper levels. I had heard this Museum has an excellent presentation on holograms which is on the 2nd floor but unfortunately this was closed. So the art collection - as you enter some examples of officials of the British Colonial Administration. Not of much interest to me. Moving on nice ethnic art of all sorts. You can see the influence of Picasso for example in works by Narasimma Murthy - very impressive. Excellent portrait of Gandhi by KV Vaidayanathan - Father of the nation - a great tribute. Some mogul art paintings . Excellent collection but less than excellent lighting. As it goes, not too many attendants in the museum so I chose to alter the lighting if I wanted to take photos - of course returning it to the original position afterwards. Excellent collection. - disappointed upper floor was closed but I guess it was being renovated. Book shop in buildings 1 and 6. Parking - anywhere you can find.

Name: Travelbug291
Title: Well Worth a Visit
Review: A somewhat confusing place if you didn't have a guide to direct you. Several galleries, the most fascinating of which was the Bronze Statue Gallery. Interesting to see the same deities interpreted from different ages. Photography is limited in some areas which is disappointing.

Name: Amjith S
Title: Many titles should be given to the different buildings which house different things for different ages too
Review: I reached there by an ola cab the driver was very interactive when i told him my drop in spot he asked me there  is nothing much to see over there. But i didn't lose my hope i took a pass and actually I was unaware of where to go I wandered there finally I spot a sign board showing direction I entered the first building and I thought its over but it wasn't there are many such buildings I feel hard to find those its better to go with our friends because we get bored watching all those stuffs which should be understood. there photography is prohibited but I managed to take some.

Name: Partha C
Title: Must see place in Chennai
Review: It is within Government Museum, separate building.   Huge collection of paintings, Art work, Sculptures. It is a must see place in Chennai.

Name: Nuno V
Title: Wonderfull Surprise
Review: In a very large city with not so many cultural and art interests the National Art Gallery is a wonderful surprise (even if many of the collections awere closed). Bronze sculpture gallery is fantastic!

Name: Ramkumar R
Title: Relaxing and Peaceful
Review: Very good collection of paintings and sculptures. If you are interested in art, this is a must visit for you in Chennai.

Name: Shyamis
Title: Not to miss for art lovers
Review: One of the oldest in India, the building itself is absolutely beautiful. It has works from mughal era, Ravi Varma, etc.

Name: ScoopTraveler
Title: Some great examples of Indian bronze sculptures and paintings poorly displayed
Review: I have rarely ever seen such a neglected and impoverished museum. Its exhibits need decent lighting and display. But for the dedicated who love art, there is plenty to be seen from Deccan to contemporary Indian paintings and wonderful bronzes from all epochs.

Name: kevinjohn1991
Title: Art lover's world!!!
Review: I would recommend this place only for real art and craft lovers who appreciate art. There are quite a few items on display like ancient books, manuscripts, stone carvings etc to name a few. This place is badly in need of repairs and maintenance * Art Lover = Must Visit *

Name: chinmayee_sahu4
Title: National Art Gallery :)
Review: A must go place for any one who appreciates art and craft and wants to dig into history. Loved my tour to Chennai :D

Name: fjp4564
Title: India's recent and past History
Review: Tourists are encouraged to visit this place that has several buildings housing inportant items like books, manuscripts, bronzes, stone carvings, coins, paintings etc.  There are some fantastic items to view in you are interested in the past History.  The many beautiful buildings looks like the way the British left them in 1948.  Badly needing some maintenance and repair work, and cleaning of the gardens etc.  it would be a national tragedy if these places are left to crumble and disappear.

Name: John S
Title: Outstanding Bronzes
Review: The museum complex has exhibits scattered theough several old Raj era buildings.  The surrounding grounds are run down, with dry fountains, broken fencing, a few pie dogs, etc., but I like that kind of atmosphere.  I only went in the Chola bronze museum and the contemporary art exhibit.  The later can be missed, it's more like a craft show, but if you're into folk art, then give it a look.  The bronzes, on the other hand, are spectacular.  These objects date mostly from the 9th to 11th centuries, are displayed well in glass cases, and have not been cleaned up, so the patina of centuries of incense and smoke remain on the surfaces.  The artistic talent that went into the crafting of these works of religious devotion is amazing.  There is a large sampling of Siva Natraj images, each one with subtle variations, and a large one at the far end of the hall that is displayed against a backdrop of a galaxy of stars, very fitting for the symbolism of the figure.  Budhist and Jain figures are also included, along with well written wall monographs on topics such as the iconography of the figures, and the various methods used to fashion the images.  Also, the room is fairly cool, always welcome in Chennai's perpetual heat.  If you are foreign, you will pay more that a native to get in, but I am glad to help support such a fine collection.  You will not find such a collection anywhere elso in the world.

Name: RooRu
Title: Interesting museum but rather shabby
Review: There are some fantastic things to see in the National Art Gallery. The Chola bronzes are a must. I also liked the massive colonial portraits and the antique furniture. The museum is very run-down, unfortunately, but still worth a visit.

Name: Siva M
Title: Feeling Very sorry. It has got 41st place in attractive list.
Review: One of a finest collections this museum has. Well kept and displayed. must visit museum in tamilnad. Non Indian can learn a lot from this site about Indian's art and culture. A perfect introduction at gate way of South.

Name: Aroundtheworldser
Title: felt sorry for the art and nature which deserve much better
Review: on a rainy day, the first in Chennai, visiting the museum was enlightening. However, the art gallery is closed for maintainance and the entire compound needs much more care. Art is beautiful, the botanical and zoological exhibits are poorly lit and the description barely lisible. Groups of school children are noisy but they do not stay long in the room anyway... Good to have seen it but do not expect much.

Name: Aline D
Title: Very good
Review: The Chola art must be seen to be appreciated.  I have said it in just a few words.....go and see south Indian art and respect the antiquity thereof!

Name: kmntgm
Title: Worth seeing...but in need of care
Review: A strange mix of art and science exhibits, in fairly poor display.  Giant dinosaurs though...The bronzes are extensive and impressive.

Name: srinivasan369
Title: Government Museum not to be missed
Review: It is what is called elsewhere "National Gallery", Pantheon Road, Egmore.This museum was established in 1857 and it is one of the finest museums in India.According to me, its "best" is the sculpture/bronze gallery which contains very nice carvings of the different Indian faiths, and, especially, a very famous Nataraja (the Lord of Dance) dancing on the demon of ignorance and surrounded by flames. There is also a nice set showing SriRama with his wife Sita and his brother Lakshmana and his devotee Hanuman, the monkey-god. There is also a fine collection of south-Indian musical instruments as well as jewellery. Timing : every day from 8am to 5pm, closed on Fridays and National holydays.

Name: becky-camille
Title: good art gallery: worth visiting
Review: This was an interesting visit to quite a good, varied and large art gallery.The gallery houses several different sections displaying art ranging from statues, bronze, contemporary, needle work, traditional and abstract. It also had random displays of plastic and details on how plastic is moulded.....:pthere are some incredibly beautiful intricate ivory works on display such as 2 jewellery boxes and a few other ornaments.worth visiting but you wont be there for more than a few hours

Name: Narayanan S
Title: A good arts gallery
Review: The selection of and display is very good. It is comparable some of the best in the country. It is kept clean. The lighting effect is also good

Name: Jackinbama
Title: How long will you be in town?
Review: We are going to be here for three years and we went here fairly early in the expatriation.  If I were just visiting I would skip this as it is depressing to see the poorly maintained property.  Some of the exhibits are interesting but overall it was disappointing.  If you're here for a long stay then I suggest waiting for cool weather.  Very few air conditioned areas in this museum.

Name: Anthony F
Title: Some wonderful exhibits
Review: There are some very interesting exhibits here in these rather run-down victorian buildings.  The exhibits are well displayed along with interesting descriptions of most pieces.The museum was quite crowded and there seemed to be a lot of school parties, but the children looked smart in their uniforms and were well behaved and supervised.Well worth visiting for a couple of hours.Their website is quite interesting and will give you a flavour of what you will find there, including a map.  http://www.chennaimuseum.org

Name: carol643
Title: bronze excellence
Review: I went here to see the wonderful collection of Chola bronzes - they range from 10th century to 14th century and the quality has never been bettered.  They are created using the 'cire perdue' technique - lost wax.  If you have any interest in Indian culture do go - its an amazing museum

Name: Lucy
Title: Nice library with a great collection
Review: A quaint library with a fantastic collection of books of all genre. The architecture of the building is itself a marvel.

Name: Raguram R
Title: Brilliant place to see
Review: This is a hidden gem and a shocker. A thing of such beauty and not publicized is something unpalatable. The library is divided into new lib and old lib. Old lib opens at 10:30am and is a hot to behold. The inside stained glasses, roof top decorations are brilliant. It is under renovation and you are not allowed to see inside. If the government were to charge 100 rupees for each visitor and tied up with tourist agencies, you will get all the money for conservation and maintenance. I would gladly donate more.The wood work supporting each book shelf is exquisite and is unique in each design.Go and see folks, and if possible petition the government to do better on this one.

Name: Mrudula
Title: publication
Review: This is a very old library with all the publications available in India and it is one of the four deposit libraries

Name: Gairik M
Title: The biggest library of Chennai
Review: The library lies along with the Egmore museum. It has a wide collection of rare books and manuscripts. The Egmore museum gives us a vivid idea of the ancient Tamil history. It even has sculptures and carvings dating back to 150 BC.

Name: Niya1315
Title: Library within Government Museum
Review: Through Connemara Public Library is in the same campus of Government Museum, no ticket is required to go inside. Good parking facility is available for 2 wheelers. You need to keep your bag outside in the designated area. Not a tourist place.

Name: Raghu1943
Title: Vast library
Review: There are several sections in this library. Periodicals have a vast variety catering to most sections of the society including technical and medical journals. It has lift facility to go to upper floors.

Name: Karpagavalli
Title: Famous among the scholars
Review: The building is inside the museum complex and the architecture is of British style as it's built by them when they were here,and houses n number of books under all topics,arthor s

Name: elleninamsterdam
Title: Da Vinci Code Library
Review: The new library might be good for reading but the old adjacent building is amazing. Would make a great movie set with the beautiful arches and stained glass windows with an amazing number of dusty paper items.

Name: Maraimalai
Title: An abode for book lovers
Review: Connemara Public library is the source of inspiration for every citizen whatever may be his educational level. It has a huge stock of books almost in all Indian languages. If you are a layman without any special interest you can take any book of your choice and get trained as an expert in any subject you want. It has journals in all languages and you can send your time happily. You can also become a member by paying a small amount and take home books of your choice. If you are a student you should not fail to utilize this opportunity. If you are a teacher you should guide your students to use it.

Name: Zinia F
Title: National Treasure
Review: Absolutely loved the ambience of the library and the vastness of the campusIt's adjacent to the museum and spellbindingly beautiful..I didn't get to explore the books section all that much to be honest as I was more interested in soaking in the vibes..Been to the permanent book fair and bought 2 books

Name: Chintan m
Title: Awesome...
Review: It is Asia‚Äôs one of the biggest library with more than 6 lac books. It has unique way of storing the books as well. Entry for entering the library is free and it is paradise for the book lovers for sure

Name: Sri S
Title: Late afternoon visit
Review: I reached the venue following an advertisement in the newspaper that a special section of the old block has been open for public viewing. we entered..no entry fee.crossed the periodicals section on the first floor.went past a corridor. climbed down and then up..we entered the place and were awestruck by the magnificent ceiling and the circular reception area.with a wide open mouth walked thru the corridors and shelves sing interesting things like census data and newspapers of all kinds.a statue of gandhiji was really aptly kept in the centre.there were books on display that are more than 400 years. palm leaf manuscripts,architecture related books and books on art. only thing that needs serious fixing is the way the newspapers are arranged.they are piled in Lots instead of being catalogued neatly.  we saw the books arranged on circular tables on the first floor. the stained glass windows panes had an ethereal quality with the afternoon sun shining thru. all in all a happy time for me and my family. we also visited the museum and the art gallery which is located in the same Pantheon compound.

Name: Arun
Title: A big and an old library in Chennai
Review: The library has old books and different sections. It is one of the best places for people who love books and you can also find a small browsing center. There is a section of the library is not accessible to public and they have restricted access.

Name: Ghiri T
Title: A place to get all the books and papers published in India
Review: It is the one of the old libraries.It is located at Egmore,Chennai.It is next to government museum.This library is named after Lord Connemara (Governor Of India) in the year 1896. It is the place where copies of all books and papers are available which are published in India.It is one of the largest libraries in Asia.

Name: Narasimhan G
Title: Excellent place to sit and read  YOUR choice of Books...
Review: Good collection of Books !From newspapers to Books they have everything to make you study !The place is adjoining the Museum !!Nearby there is a play area for Children.Annual Membership facility is there (renewable every year) Fee is very little

Name: Shankar N
Title: Massive
Review: A huge collection of books.  You can find some old.. rare books here.  Not jus the library, the nearby museum and the surrounding lawns are a good spot for some peaceful time and get soaked in the history.  Very very cheap and very good place in the midst of the city.

Name: Heiko L
Title: Make sure to find the old library
Review: At first, you enter the "new" building. It is shocking to see all the books rotting in the shelves, the claustrophobic rooms ... the years of neglect. But when you manage to find the way across to the old library (reading room first floor right back corner), it becomes a different story altogether.

Name: Karan440
Title: Famous and old library
Review: It is one of the famous and old libraries in Asia. Here you can find lot of old books and there are many sections as well. People who love reading must visit this place atleast once.

Name: Kymosavvy
Title: There is also a 'hidden' library that is a must see
Review: The public library is interesting but if you go out of the main library using the overhead tunnel bridge you will come to a part that is not open to the public but is a real hidden gem, beautiful stained glass windows, fantastic old teak library shelves stuffed with books including one of the first bikes in Chennai. Up stairs there are piles,of books all over the floor, beautiful Victorian architecture and is a real treasure. We just asked if we could see and were very lucky to be allowed access.

Name: Sundeepgupta
Title: Old and good
Review: This is a well known public library in Chennai and its collection is huge. The library can be visited if you are a book lover

Name: Pradeep K
Title: Oldest library in Chennai
Review: One of the National Depository Libraries in India which would receive a copy of all the books, newspaper & periodicals published in India. It has a mammoth collection but readers misplace the books which makes is extremely difficult to locate the book we're looking for.

Name: Mathivanan V
Title: What more you Neeeed
Review: What more you need ,When you get whatever you are searching for.Friendly Librarian and computer system to help you in locating your book need.Only thing is over crowded and poorly maintained place.The place needs a urgent makeover and renovation.Once done there cant be a better place for Bookworms.

Name: gullu2014
Title: Book Palace
Review: I frequently visit Connemara Library. No membership is needed for reading books here. In case you want to borrow books from here, you need to become a member. There are totally four floors. All kinds of books are there. It is very useful for mu academic purpose. The library is air conditioned and comfortable.

Name: rea2der
Title: Connemara library
Review: Recently I visited this library.The library is too old one and not maintained properly.We have a huge collection of old and new books available.We have membership options too.We have amul milk parlor nearby wherein we can have some good milk and now we have offers for book purchase too.

Name: Aaqarsh Aiyyar
Title: A Knowledge mine
Review: Connemara public library is one of my favourite place in the city. The library stacks a wide range of books, magazines, journals, e-books and more. I had spent a lot of time here during my M.Phil dissertation and it has helped me immensely to widen my knowledge and deepen my understanding in a variety of fields.

Name: Krishang S
Title: Excellent
Review: Excellent Library in Tamil Nadu, you cannot see these type of library will all types of books It is a heaven for Students and also professionals For Students they will get excellent knowledge with varieties of books and for each varietythey can see thousands of booksFor Professionals based upon the profession they can select books,For each profession topics the books are more

Name: Balasubramanian R
Title: University of Madras
Review: university of Madras is one of the oldest university and proud got my postgraudation through this university. Is is located nearer to  Marina beach and with vast area. Different departments, library etc are functioning here.  I too worked as a part time employee, during my college days

Name: ST_INDIA
Title: One of the oldest university in India
Review: This is one of the oldest university in India which is situated right opposite to the Marina beach and the building is like ones of the British era. This is surely the most prestigious university in Tamil Nadu one of the most popular ones in India.

Name: Karpagavalli
Title: onemore British era building
Review: This is one of the famous universities of the state and so vast with beautiful building,nice garden, and is overlooking the sea.

Name: vinodkhedkar
Title: Nice University
Review: I happened to visit this place due to my friend who was studying there earlier. This university has a long history of education.Nice campus.

Name: vasan224
Title: public state university
Review: it was established in 1857, it is one of the oldest and premier universities in India.It is a collegiate research university and has six campuses in the city viz., Chepauk, Marina, Guindy, Taramani, Maduravoyal and Chetpet. At present, there are 73 academic departments grouped under 18 schools, covering diverse areas such as sciences, social sciences, humanities, management and medicine along with 109 affiliated colleges and 52 approved research institutions.

Name: vijmail99
Title: Huge campus
Review: Huge campus and a prestigious institution. But foul smell due to the sewage flow nearby. Lot of trees. Prepare for a lot of walking.

Name: s_ramsam
Title: British legacy
Review: This landmark building in Chennai presently housing the university is a lovely legacy of the British era. Fine architecture and well located facing the sprawling Marina beach.

Name: James H
Title: Excellent Architecture
Review: This is a huge rambling place to visit. It is one of the oldest universities in India (chartered in 1857) and it is a glorious collection of Indo-Saracenic architecture. I gave a talk here on my last visit and had the chance to poke into some of the incredible buildings. Do try to find Senate House if you have the time and image what it was like it its heyday.  It is lovely place for a stroll anytime. Perhaps a bit tatty around the edges but it has that magical sense of former students over the ages.

Name: Rucha121
Title: Oldest University in India
Review: One of the oldest and prestigious institute in India for education, offers lots of courses - UG & PG and many colleges are affiliated to this. Located near Marina Beach,

Name: Anusuya D
Title: landmark at chennai
Review: old building of educational institutions. landmark at chennai , situated at beach road. santuary for students.

Name: krish862
Title: one of the oldest temple for education
Review: The university is world famous and very old . Even the construction , we can see best architecture available in those good olden days..Present maintainance is not good

Name: Perry Grinate
Title: must see for fans of Indo-Saracenic architecture
Review: Robert Chisholm's Senate House is breathtaking from the outside.  Walk inside (no-one stopped me) and a desolate picture of an interior populated only by birds opens up.  Other Indo-saracenic buildings to visit (I hired a tuk tuk for a morning for 800 rupees and did a round trip) are the railway station, Ripon Building, Victoria Hall and Bharat Insurance Building

Name: Jothilingam E
Title: Very old university
Review: One of the oldest universities in India and also in Asia.This is in beach road and opposite to famous marina beach,government office,many memorials like leaders,Anna,MGR,Jayalilitha etc.The university offers many cources and do not to visit library and university centenary hall where all convocations happen

Name: balakec
Title: Best Place to checkout the Indo-Sarcenic Architecture
Review: Madras University is one of the oldest universities of Asia. The place is opposite to the Marina Beach. The campus has loads of colonial era red brick buildings. Special mention to the Senate House which is designed in Indo-Sarcenic architectures which blends both native indian along with persian(mughal) architecture.

Name: Shankar N
Title: Visit it for the building style
Review: Though this is an educational institution, i like it because of its architecture.  Old buildings built in the colonial style.. long walkways.. high ceiling and cool interiors..

Name: Ameet_Pathare
Title: Colonial Charm..!
Review: Located opposite marina beach the grandeur of university cannot be described.The majestic architecture buildings have their own charm.Visitors are not allowed to enter the premises

Name: Mohan2013
Title: Memorable place
Review: Situated on the marina beach, the second longest and most beautiful beach of the world. The seat of education that produced great scholars snd administrators. A very old building and one of the oldest varieties in India. Proud to be a student of tbd university.

Name: ganeshpkumar
Title: Huge and grand structures
Review: Located just opposite to the marina beach, this University is a testimony to the architectural influence of the British Rule. The place covers a vast area with beautiful buildings and trees. The sad part is that they are not much well maintained.

Name: YatriForever
Title: Old, colonial buildings
Review: Having been a student of this once prestigious University, it is sad to see  the poor upkeep of these amazing heritage buildings. Unfortunately, not many in the University's administration can explain/answer specific questions about the legacy of these grand structures. Just a ice place to visit, if you happen to be in Marina Beach.

Name: NafiRiz
Title: More than a century old
Review: This red colored, historic colonial architecture is a beautiful educational campus. Its a big property and is surrounded by loads n loads of trees. It is opposite to the marina beach.

Name: Unni2006
Title: University of Madras
Review: This is one of the oldest universities at chennai which offers all variety of specialisations. . Located on the Marina Beach Road , it normally confuses the public between Anna University at Guindy and the University of Madras. Beautiful old architecture is another attraction over here. Very popular among the local people.

Name: Arrul
Title: Senate building is the one to look for!!!1
Review: Senate building,one of the beautiful and  considered to be one of the best and oldest examples of Indo-Saracenic architecture in India.

Name: AshokMela
Title: Prestigious University !!
Review: University of Madras commonly referred as Madras University is located opposite to Marina beach. This is one of the biggest and oldest university in southern India. The colonial architecture depicts the same. The campus has some very big trees that me be couple of centuries old.

Name: Karthik V
Title: Oldest and Prestigious University
Review: The University of Madras is One of the Oldest and Prestigious University in Chennai. Its majestic structure overlooking the long Marina Beach and the pristine blue waters is wonderful to see and study its architure.

Name: Shyamis
Title: A very old university and a good place to visit
Review: Love visiting the university campus every once in a while. The library is good, The buildings are really old and interesting and in general it is a nice place to visit

Name: Pulak
Title: Colonial Architecture at its Best
Review: Located very close to Marina Beach, the University of Madras building is an architectural marvel. Visited from outside and felt very impressed

Name: Je L
Title: Good University
Review: This university is located by a beautiful beach.  You can enjoy the beach and visit this university.  It is also historical place.

Name: andrewwray2512
Title: Stunning colonial architecture
Review: It's definitely worth strolling along to the University of Madras to take a peek at the stunning colonial architecture set amongst leafy grounds by the beach. The security guards will probably try to stop you taking photos, (for unknown reasons), but it's worth the hassle even just to look.

Name: vidyutm
Title: nice landscape
Review: University of madras located opposite Marina beach of chennai. you can see historic building of this educational campus.

Name: Bhargava Krishna
Title: Historical University
Review: Almost 120 years aged building. Impressive look. Near to marina beach. Many great scientists and film makers studied here.

Name: bigbobadams
Title: Cool Old Buildings Near Marina Beach
Review: This is a university, so not really a tourist attraction for visitors. There are some really cool old buildings on campus with the classic British architecture. It is right across the Anna Memorial and northern starting point of Marina Beach.

Name: Mathivanan V
Title: Very old British Structure
Review: Built by British Governor ,It is very good to look from outside but it is really pathetic once you are in.Anyone visiting Marina beach can see this marvel from outside  even click a snap or two.If you don't have any other work you can step inside and visit the Library.A very good library to spend some time.And nothing else it offers.

Name: SagarVS
Title: Not for the visitor
Review: Unless you have business here, there is no need to enter the place. If you are visiting the marina  beach you could take a look at the impressive building from outside.

Name: Neeraj P
Title: Nice place!
